container-title: The doyen of Crusade historians is Jonathan Riley-Smith, whose The First Crusade and the Idea of Crusading
title: The Crusades have received a great deal of attention from historians, not least in recent years. Major volumes by Christopher Tyerman, God’s War: A New History of the Crusades
Jonathan Phillips, Holy Warriors: A Modern History of the Crusades
The Crusades: The War for the Holy Land
take different approaches to the Crusades. Each provides a compelling overview and demonstrates that scholarship about the subject is in robust health
is still indispensable. His many other works about the Crusades in general and about the first expedition to Jerusalem in particular are invaluable – not least The First Crusaders 1095–1131
provides a fine military history of the expedition to Jerusalem. Also see Thomas Asbridge’s very readable The First Crusade: A New History

note: The best are Jonathan Phillips’
title: There are a number of edited volumes based on conferences held to commemorate the nine hundredth anniversary of the Council of Clermont with collections of papers by leading scholars

note: historians have written surprisingly little about this subject. One exception is Jonathan Harris’ clear and useful
title: The First Crusade: Origins and Impact
Michel Balard’s Autour de la Première Croisade
The Crusades and Crusader Societies
Other edited volumes to recommend include Crusade and Settlement
Norman Housely further reading 239 and Jonathan Phillips
Also see Thomas Madden’s well-chosen collection of essays by leading scholars, The Crusades
Alan Murray’s bibliography for the First Crusade is also invaluable

note: Carole Hillenbrand’s The Crusades, Islamic Perspectives (Edinburgh, 1999) is extremely helpful in looking at the west from the east.
title: Not to be missed is Paul Magdalino’s ‘The Byzantine background to the First Crusade’, in Canadian Institute of Balkan Studies

Likewise Ralph-Johannes Lilie’s excellent study of Byzantine relations with the Crusaders, first published in German in 1981, available in a fine translation as Byzantium and the Crusader States 1096–1204 (tr
Anna Komnene and Her Times

note: Liubarskii’s ‘Ob istochnikakh “Aleksiady” Anny Komninoi’, Vizantiiskii Vremennik 25
title: John France’s ‘Anna Comnena, the Alexiad and the First Crusade’
gives a western Crusade view of the text. The best major deconstruction of the Alexiad’s chronology was done by Iakov Liubarskii ‘Zamechaniya k khronologii XI Knigi “Aleksiada” Anny Komninoi’
who examined the problems of Book XI of the Alexiad. This is reprised and advanced by Lilie in Appendix 1 of Byzantium and the Crusader States
The mistakes in the positioning of individual episodes elsewhere in the text have been noted by David Gress-Wright, ‘Bogomilism in Constantinople’
Discours de Théophylacte de Bulgarie’
L’Abjuration du moine Nil le Calabrais’

remains the best attempt to identify the range of sources available to Anna Komnene, as well as picking up on several other instances where the Alexiad is chronologically flawed. A major new study of Anna Komnene’s work is needed to identify the full extent of the problems of the history’s sequence of events

container-title: The Crusades and their Sources: Essays presented to Bernard Hamilton
Also Hillenbrand’s ‘The First Crusade: The Muslim perspective’, in Phillips, First Crusade

The letter from Alexios I to Robert of Flanders has been roundly dismissed, Peter Schreiner, ‘Der Brief des Alexios I Komnenos an den Grafen Robert von Flandern und das Problem gefälschter byzantinischer Kaiserschreiben in den westlichen Quellen’, and Christian Gastgeber, ‘Das Schreiben Alexios I. Komnenos an Robert I. Flandern. Sprachliche Untersuchung’, both in Giuseppe de Gregorio and Otto Kresten (eds.), Documenti medievali Greci e Latini: Studi Comparativi
note: though also see Carole Sweetenham, ‘Two letters calling Christians on Crusade’, in Robert the Monk’s History of the First Crusade (Aldershot,
Both however consider the Byzantine position in Asia Minor to be positively healthy in the early 1090s. Note therefore
title: the first crusade For the western narrative sources for the Crusade, a good starting point is Colin Morris, ‘The Gesta Francorum as Narrative History’

More recently, however, see John France’s ‘The anonymous Gesta Francorum and the Historia Francorum qui ceperunt Iherusalem of Raymond of Aguilers and the Historia de Hierosolymitano itinere of Peter Tudebode: An analysis of the textual relationship between primary sources for the First Crusade’
Also see France’s ‘The use of the anonymous Gesta Francorum in the early twelfthcentury sources for the First Crusade’, in Alan Murray, From Clermont to Jerusalem: The Crusades and Crusader Societies
What is the Gesta Francorum and who was Peter Tudebode?’
Albert of Aachen reappraised’
Also see Edgington’s ‘The First Crusade: Reviewing the evidence’
and Marc Carrier’s ‘L’image d’Alexis Ier Comnène selon le chroniqueur Albert d’Aix’
The Hebrew First Crusade Chronicles’
La lettre d’Alexis Comnène à Robert Ier le Frison’

container-title: and Alfons Becker’s magisterial Papst Urban II 1088–99
For the papacy, H. E. J. Cowdrey’s Pope Gregory
title: The papacy and western Europe at the time of the First Crusade There are any number of outstanding studies about Europe on the eve of the Crusade

note: is important, as is Josef Deér’s Papsttum und further reading 241 Normannen: Untersuchungen zu ihren lehnsrechtlichen und kirchenpolitischen
title: are essential. Cowdrey’s The Age of Abbot Desiderius: Montecassino, the Papacy and the Normans in the Eleventh and Early Twelfth Centuries

note: provides a convincing commentary on Rome’s struggles in this period.
title: Ian Robinson’s The Papacy 1073–1198

container-title: Communications and Power in Medieval Europe: The Gregorian Revolution and Beyond
Also worth seeing here is Aristeides Papadakis and John Meyendorff, The Christian East and the Rise of the Papacy: The Church 1071–1453
and above all Axel Bayer’s Spaltung der Christenheit: Das sogenannte Morgenländische Schisma von 1054
note: Errors of the Latins (Urbana, 2000) is helpful on the rivalry between the Eastern and Western churches. For the investiture crisis, see Ute-Renata Blumenthal’s The Investiture Controversy: Church and Monarchy from the Ninth to the Twelfth Century (Philadelphia, 1988) and Gerd Tellenbach, The Western Church from the Tenth to the Early Twelfth Century (Cambridge, 1993).
title: The same author’s Henry IV of Germany, 1056–1106
is excellent on the crises in Europe in the late eleventh century. The collected works of Timothy Reuter
Medieval Polities and Modern Mentalities
offer much food for thought. Steven Runciman’s Eastern Schism: A Study of the Papacy and the Eastern Churches During the Eleventh and Twelfth Centuries

still provides a clear narrative of the events of 1054, though Henry Chadwick’s East and West: The Making of a Rift in the Church: From Apostolic Times Until the Council of Florence (Oxford, 2003) puts the schism in a wider context
Tia Kolbaba’s The Byzantine Lists

2002) and the Cambridge History of Byzantine Empire, c.500–1492
2008) provide introductions to the Byzantine Empire in general that are clear and often provocative
is also excellent, if monumental. There are some outstanding collections of essays on Constantinople

container-title: On the economy, see Alan Harvey, Economic Expansion in the Byzantine Empire (900–1200
note: Michael Metcalf ’s Coinage in South-Eastern Europe (Oxford, 1979) is still essential, as is his article ‘The reformed gold coinage of Alexius I Comnenus’, in Hamburger Beiträge zur Numismatik,
For the debasement of the currency in the eleventh century, see Cécile Morrisson, ‘La Dévaluation de la monnaie byzantine au XIe siècle’, Travaux et Mémoires 6
further reading 243
title: Kinship and the distribution of power in Komnenian Byzantium’
For the army under Alexios and his successors, John Birkenmeier, The Development of the Komnenian Army: 1081–1180
though Armin Hohlweg, Beiträge zur Verwaltunsgeschichte des oströmischen Reiches unter den Komnenen (Munich, 1965) still has much to say. Paul Magdalino’s The Empire of Manuel I Komnenos 1143–1180
is worth reading not only for Alexios’ successors, but also as a backdrop to the composition of the Alexiad. For this, also see Paul Stephenson, ‘The Alexiad as a source for the Second Crusade’
and his important piece on ‘The land and taxation in the reign of Alexios I Komnenos: The evidence of Theophylakt of Ochrid’

and ‘Coinage, wealth and plunder in the age of Robert Guiscard’

title: Jean-Marie Martin’s La Pouille du VIe au XIIe siècles (Rome, 1993) remains the benchmark for surveys of southeastern Italy. The recent article by Paul Oldfield, ‘Urban government in southern Italy, c.1085–c.1127’

note: and Matthew Bennett, ‘Norman naval activity in the Mediterranean c.1060–1108’, Anglo-Norman
title: For Byzantine relations with the Normans, see Huguette Taviani-Carozzi, La Terreur du monde – Robert Guiscard et la conquête normande en Italie
Articles by William McQueen, ‘Relations between the Normans and Byzantium 1071–1112’

offer helpful examinations of the attacks on Byzantium. The trade treaty with Venice is of crucial importance, and has been looked at exhaustively. Thomas Madden’s ‘The chrysobull of Alexius I Comnenus 244 the first crusade to the Venetians: The date and the debate’

note: and also ‘Challenges to imperial authority in Byzantium: Revolts on Crete and Cyprus at the end of the
title: is excellent; however, I have major doubts about the internal evidence in the text of the grant, not least about the date; see my article, ‘Byzantine trade privileges to Venice in the eleventh century: The chrysobull of 1092’

For concerns about other episodes in the 1090s, all stemming from problems with the chronology of the Alexiad, see pieces I have written on ‘The Fall of Nicaea and the towns of western Asia Minor to the Turks in the later 11th Century: The curious case of Nikephoros Melissenos’

Crusade message very well, such as Penny Cole, The Preaching of the Crusades to the Holy Land

title: his ‘The idea of Crusading in the Charters of Early Crusaders’
is useful as well, as is Christopher Tyerman, ‘Who went on crusades to the Holy Land?’, in Horns of Hattin

Marcus Bull’s Knightly Piety and the Lay Response to the First Crusade: The Limousin and Gascony (Oxford, 1993) provides a compelling and meticulous view of one region of France. Also note John France, ‘Les origines de la Première Croisade: un nouvel examen’
For millenarianism in the late eleventh century, see Hannes Möhring, Der Weltkaiser der Endzeit: Entstehung Wandel und Wirkung einer tausendjährigen Weissagung
Dominion of God: Christendom and Apocalypse in the Early Middle Ages

For more specialised studies on the impact and origins of the First Crusade, see Michele Gabriele, ‘Against the enemies of Christ: The role of Count Emicho further reading 245 in the Anti-Jewish Violence of the First Crusade’
Christian Attitudes towards the Jews in the Middle Ages: A Casebook
“Let not a remnant or a residue escape”: Millenarian enthusiasm in the First Crusade’
Several recommendations can be made when it comes to practical issues to do with the expedition
The army of Godfrey of Bouillon 1096–9: Structure and dynamics of a contingent on the First Crusade’
First Crusaders and the costs of crusading’
Travel and transport of the Crusades’
The rate of march of crusading armies in Europe: A study and computation’

note: Nevertheless, Ralph Yewdale’s Bohemond I: Prince of Antioch (Princeton, 1924) is enduringly charming. Jean Flori’s Bohémond d’Antioche: Chevalier d’aventure (Paris, 2007) is more up to date. For Raymond of Toulouse, John and Laurita Hill, Raymond IV, Count of Toulouse (Syracuse, 1962). For Robert of Normandy, William Aird’s recent Robert ‘Curthose’, Duke of Normandy (c.1050–1134) (Woodbridge, 2008). For Godfrey of Bouillon, Pierre Aubé, Godefroy de Bouillon (Paris, 1985).
